summary: This is a grand jury subpoena issued by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to JPMorgan Chase Bank, demanding extensive financial records for an investigation into alleged violations of federal statutes including bribery, conspiracy, false statements, and obstruction. The subpoena includes detailed instructions for document production and a procedure for reimbursement of costs.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: Issued and signed the grand jury subpoena as the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

persons.name: Ed Tyrrell
persons.context: Contact person for advance permission if estimated reimbursement costs exceed $500, as mentioned in the accompanying procedure letter.

events.title: Grand Jury Appearance Date
events.description: Scheduled date for JPMorgan Chase Bank to appear before the grand jury to testify and produce documents, though appearance can be waived if records are produced earlier.

events.title: Subpoena Issuance
events.description: Date the grand jury subpoena was issued and signed by the U.S. Attorney, demanding financial records from JPMorgan Chase Bank.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, Room 220, Manhattan, New York, NY
JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. National Subpoena Processing Center, 7610W Washington Street, Indianapolis, IN 46231
U.S. Attorney's Office, 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
U.S. Attorney's Office - SDNY Accounts Payable, 86 Chambers Street, 3rd floor, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The subpoena targets JPMorgan Chase Bank for records related to accounts and transactions from January 1, 2019, onward, indicating an active financial investigation.

The investigation involves alleged violations of multiple federal statutes: 18 U.S.C. §§ 201 (bribery), 371 (conspiracy), 1001 (false statements), 1346 (honest services fraud), 1519 (destruction/alteration of records), and 2 (aiding and abetting).
The requested documents are extensive, including account opening documents, statements, wire transfers, check images, credit card records, and customer identification information.
The subpoena includes a detailed rider specifying electronic production requirements for transaction data, emphasizing the need for structured financial data analysis.
A procedure for reimbursement of costs to the financial institution is outlined, referencing the Right to Financial Privacy Act, with Ed Tyrrell as the contact for high-cost approvals.
